Students who chose eLearning for the entire first nine weeks of the semester will continue to log in to Zoom for daily instruction.

post_text: Bay Village Schools has once again earned the prestigious designation of a Best Music Education Community in America! We have, since 2003, been recognized for outstanding commitment of school administrators, community leaders, teachers and parents who believe in music education and are working to ensure that it is part of a well-rounded education for all children. Data is then analyzed statistically and verified via a follow-up audit by researchers at The Music Research Institute at the University of Kansas.

Our latest FAQ: What will happen to the Spring Musical?

A: We have a tentative plan to reschedule the performances for July 10 at 7 p.m. and July 11 at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. This is, of course, is dependent on the ban on gatherings being lifted by Governor DeWine. As new information becomes available, we will have a clearer picture as to whether this will become a reality, but we are hopeful that we will be able to proceed. Please understand that we have and will continue to do everything in our power to provide the opportunity for the students to perform, but as always, their safety and the safety of our community is our primary concern. We appreciate your understating as we navigate this unprecedented situation. (Note: We are working with our ticket vendors to process refunds for the cancelled shows. Ticket information for these rescheduled shows will be available in early June.)
Check back often as we get MORE answers to your questions: http://bit.ly/BayCOVID19FAQs

Mrs. Carrie Singler is using video to keep students engaged with their strings lessons. Is it any wonder we are a Best Music Education Community in America? Mrs. Singler explains her process:
"Normally I teach an Irish fiddle tune by rote for St. Patrick's Day. So I filmed a series of videos breaking down the tune through calls and responses. And because I took home every type of string instrument (a violin & viola, a cello and a double bass--my car was packed leaving school last Friday!) I was able to make how-to videos breaking down the challenges for every instrument. I look forward to getting videos back of them playing this year's fiddle tune and hope they include them in the Living Room Concerts they are doing."

post_text: Parents learned tonight that early is way better when investing in their child's future. Bob Gillingham (BHS alumnus and financial literacy specialist) shared the "miracle of compound interest," the wisdom of index stock investing, and other strategies to ensure an ample college fund once those Birth-Grade 12 years whiz by. Char Shryock, our district's Director of Teaching and Learning, shared how the investment of parental time coupled with four learning investment strategies will have children ready to make the most of scholarship opportunities and other higher education choices. Find resources at: http://iteachbay.blogspot.com/p/summer-parent-resources.html

Thirty-three Bay High School student artists and writers garnered a total of 67 awards at the Annual Greater Cleveland Scholastic Art + Writing Competition and Exhibition hosted by the Cleveland Institute of Art.

Twenty-one Bay High students received Art Awards, winning 13 Gold Key, 11 Silver Key and 22 Honorable Mention Awards. Twelve Bay high students received Writing Awards, winning 5 Gold Key, 9 Silver Key and 7 Honorable Mention Awards. Gold Key recipients will have their work judged at the national competition held each spring in New York City. The Cleveland exhibit is going on now. Details at: http://bit.ly/BHSScholasticArtWriting
Pictured from left: Masha Waiss and Chloe Rickson, both Gold Key Art Award winners, at Cleveland Institute of Art Scholastic Art + Writing Exhibit. (Photo by Greg Hildebrandt.)
